UI-WELCOME_ERROR: Kibana did not load properly. Check the server output for more information.
KIBANA-CREATE_INDEX_PATTERN_STEP_1_INFO_: Index patterns are used to match indices
Kibana uses index patterns to decide which Elasticsearch indices to run search and analytics against. Kibana also uses index patterns to configure fields.
For example, "logstash-*" will match all indices that begin with "logstash-".
KIBANA-EXPAND_INDEX_PATTERN_HELP_1: With this option selected, searches against any time-based index pattern which contains a wildcard will automatically expand to query only the indices which contain data within the currently selected time range.
KIBANA-EXPAND_INDEX_PATTERN_HELP_2: Searching against the index pattern 'logstash-*' will actually query Elasticsearch for the specific matching indices (e.g. 'logstash-2015.12.21') that fall within the current time range.
KIBANA-EXPAND_INDEX_PATTERN_HELP_3: With recent changes to Elasticsearch, this option should no longer be necessary and will likely be removed in future versions of Kibana.
KIBANA-CREATE_INDEX_PATTERN_STEP_2_SUB_T: You've defined {{indexPatternName}} as your index pattern. Now you can specify some optional settings before we create it.
KIBANA-CREATE_INDEX_PATTERN_STEP_2_TIME_: Choose optional Time Filter field name
The Time Filter will use this field to filter your data by time.
KIBANA-NO_DATE_FIELD_DESIRED: I don't want to use the Time Filter
KIBANA-INDICES_DONT_CONTAIN_TIME_FIELDS: The indices which match this index pattern don't contain any time fields.
KIBANA-NO_INDICES_MATCHING_PATTERN: Could not locate any indices matching that pattern. Please add the index to Elasticsearch
KIBANA-NO_DEFAULT_INDEX_PATTERN: No default index pattern. You must select or create one to continue.
KIBANA-INDICES_MATCH_PATTERN: Unable to fetch mapping. Do you have indices matching the pattern?
